I've got an in-person atheist book club. I'm, I'm attending Wednesday. Um, I've been a part of that
for a year on and off, but, uh, that being in person when I did both of my interviews with David
Smalley was in person, came here in person to talk. Yeah. And so I, you know, it's hard for us to be
everywhere and social media kind of gives us that quasi omnipotence or omniscience, right? But, but
I think it's much more effective to be, well, the conversations that happen before and after the
actual conversation and debate or sometimes, and I think probably the biggest impact we had on David
was when we took him and his family to dinner after the entire debate. And I had two meaningful
conversations with him after we turned the mic off. Right. And in fact, we had built up such a
rapport the first time that before he went, we went live. He's like, Hey man, just be ready for a
punch in the face and clicked on the button. But I knew that because I listened to him. Yeah,
exactly. But he turned the mic off and he's like, Oh, you did really good, man. Yeah, exactly. Yes.
So that was a good show. And so, but there was some, there was some rapport there. And so I think,
you know, you gotta love, you gotta love this stuff. Um, you can, I struggle with this one.
She got to love people. There's a little meme on the social media, a little kid, a little short.
He goes, he's like a toddler. He's like two. He goes, Oh no, people.
That's my lifelong problem. But, but you love the Lord, your God with all your heart, mind,
soul and strength, loving neighbors yourself. I mean, what are we back to the two greatest
commandments, you know? And it's good. It's not, we're not for the grace of God. And none of us
would even be striving toward those things, but the mind and the relationships and loving others,
loving Jesus, loving God with everything we got, and then loving other people.
So I have a question because one thing that we've unpacked over, um, over the kind of the
life of this podcast is the, um, the concept of hermeneutics and the importance of that. And so,
can you maybe point out some things that kind of that you can see from a hermeneutics standpoint,
from these interviews that were maybe good or just worth, worth noting, especially about,
because I think about like when, um, when a Huff is talking to Mark Minard and talking about what
the Bible is like, why the Bible was written, those types of things. Can you speak to any of,
any of that to where it's like, one, the importance of hermeneutics in that specific conversation,
but then also as people are having those conversations, how hermeneutics can continue
to help inform. Absolutely. And hermeneutics can be very intimidating. I think, I mean,
it was for me, I took a year of language and seminary in, uh, Hebrew and Greek. And, uh,
you're always asking yourself the question, do I have the right hermeneutic? Basically,
it's just a way of interpreting the text by what, by what strap, by what foundation are we
approaching the text of scripture? And, um, so I think what, what West did very intelligently
was not only give you a history of the documents, but, but pointed it to Christ. So like in Luke 24,
where Jesus is walking on the road to Emmaus with the disciples. And, uh, Luke tells us that
beginning with Moses and all the prophets, he spoke to them, the things concerning himself
in all the scriptures. So the foundational, I wish you had that. Oh man.
What a sermon. I can't believe you didn't read it. No one wrote that down. Oh man. Come on guys.
But they were, but we get a hint of why they didn't write it down. They were walking along
the road and they were sad. Yeah. You know, so there's where, there's where melancholy causes
you to miss out on the sermon notes. Um, but, but, but really, as I, as we said earlier, um,
all these cults and other religions have something to say about Jesus. Right. So the hermeneutic of,
of scripture, the ultimate one to simplify it for our audience. I mean, hermeneutics, you can buy
thousand page books on her. And we have several podcasts about it too. And so it's a very
intricate detailed sort of thing as you guys know. But I think there's two things that have to,
before we get into the textual arguments about it, there are two things that I think are prerequisite
for how do you even begin the question of hermeneutics? And that is Jesus and love because
Paul says in first Corinthians, if you don't have love, um, you're just talking about dry macaroni
and cheese, right? You don't have any, you can explain all mysteries, but if you don't have love,
you know, so, so the idea that, that understanding text is somewhat separate from our devotional
life to Jesus, uh, or separate from Jesus or somehow that, that devotional life isn't related
to the intellectual side of what we're talking about, that I always approach hermeneutics in
terms of, okay, how does this passage point me to Christ? Um, and you can, you can go overboard
with that of course, but, uh, if Jesus statement about the old Testament, Moses and all the prophets
are true, then there's no reason to think that we couldn't find tinctures of who Christ is in, in
throughout the scriptures and that we should, and that we shouldn't like, like with Carson,
you know, his, if he does have a, we all have a hermeneutic and Carson's hermeneutics. Sometimes
we use hermeneutics to support our pet ideas. We can do that too, you know, and, and, and it's to
some, to some degree, the end result of that is ending up where you are with somebody like Billy
Carson or, um, young earth versus old earth creationism. If that becomes more important to
you, then your whole hermeneutic is related to the age of the universe or, you know, the early
Gnostic heresies or the early heresies about the Trinity or about Christ. Um, it was more,
more a philosophical personal point of view than it was a view that is trying to honor and glorify
Christ. Because what's the role of the Holy Spirit to bring to mind the things that Jesus taught to
convict the world of sin and to glorify God. So to glorify Christ specifically to remind us of who
Jesus is. And so if the Holy Spirit is functioning, then Christ is the center of your hermeneutic.
And if Christ is the center of your hermeneutic, then you're going to love people. But through
that process of sanctification, it's not going to be perfect. Um, even Wes had a nine minute video
about all the mistakes he made and he said at the end of it, look, I'm perf, I'm not perfect.
Don't look to me like I'm perfect, right? I'm not the perfect one. Jesus is the only one that's
perfect. Right. Of course. So I think for me, my hermeneutic filter when, before I go deep diving
into academic side of things is to understand, am I trying to make Jesus the focal point of this?
And am I doing this in love rather than just wanting to argue with somebody? I don't know
if that answers your question or not, but that's a simple breakdown of that. Yeah. Yeah. I think
that's good. Encouraging people as they have these, um, conversations and as they're doing the research
when they're looking up the things they're passionate about, like you were asking, and then
that's part of why we have a local church community is when you go, well, I found these
four websites and I don't know if they don't agree with you. Like what, what's right here?
What's wrong? Who is this? You know, you could find a Billy Carson website when you ask the
question. And so that's part of the church community as you go to your church community
and you talk to your lay leaders and pastors and have that conversation with them like,
and with other leaders and with other believers, like Philip and the Ethiopian, right? Exactly.
Who's going to help me understand who's going to help me understand this. And so
I think that's healthy part of why we need those communities. So to wrap up on this one,
and then what sounds like, well, maybe even do just a whole other one on Joe on the Rogan one,
but is, is that whether you're on Joe Rogan and you have 11 million viewers or your conversation
with your unbelieving, you know, brother at Thanksgiving, those are all the gospel in action
equally. And if the body of Christ modality that Paul teaches us, if he means that for real,
then we have, we are part of Wes Huff's conversation with Joe Rogan and he is part of our conversation
with our brother or sister or family member. Like those are all integrated, all parts of
the body. I want to make sure to emphasize that this stuff goes viral on YouTube.
That's not our aim. Right. Exactly. Not, I mean, it's not wrong to go viral on YouTube,
but, but don't, I think, and Brandon mentioned it earlier, we can be overwhelmed
by the success of Christians. I am not like that person, Susie so-and-so or John so-and-so
or pastor so-and-so. If I was, if I could only be half the person that they are and we
look at each other and each other's ministries that God has equipped us with, but I love Paul's
analogy of the body. The hand can't say to the eye. I don't need you. The body is a wonderful analogy
because it needs all the parts to function. The heart needs, the eyes need the heart and the feet
need the heart and the lungs and it all is a working organism together. And that's, so your
part may be unseen. And I think even Paul says something about the parts that are unseen, having
more of an importance than the parts that are to some degree. I don't know the exact wording there,
but that, that don't make social media and the success of other Christians your aim. Don't think
you have to talk to an atheist like I've talked to Carson. That's a mistake I make. I want to be
like that guy. I want to be the answer man who can just spout off in 24 hours notice. I can just
rattle off stuff about the New Testament and about all that stuff. I would have needed much more time
to prepare to talk to Billy because I didn't know anything about him, but you know, some of the
stuff that he brought up, I had to look it up, you know? So don't be ashamed to say, I don't know,
but constantly strive to make sure that, that, that you, you are in accord with God preparing you
to give a defense or the hope that is in you. Because it's all by grace that we
can open our mouth and say anything anyway. Here we go. Very good.
Thank you for joining us for this episode of Reconstructed Faith. If you enjoyed what you
heard or were challenged, please leave us a review. It'll help other people find us.
If you have questions or a topic you'd like to hear discussed, shoot me an email
at info at southspring.org. Reconstructed Faith is a resource of South Spring Baptist Church.
Remember, don't give up. Trust God. Search for answers.
